segments.text: OK, this is an interview with Dr. Jim Adams by Matthew Moran on the 20th of April 1993 at Cref Brazos Baptist Association concerning the effect of the civil rights movement on the Southern Baptist Church.
Dr. Adams, I'm asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M oral history collection in the university archives.
Is that all right with you?
That's fine.
Thank you.
OK, Dr. Adams, where were you born?
I was born in Temple, Texas in 1929.
OK. And did you grow up in Temple also?
No.
My father was a railroad engineer, was working in Palestine, Texas shortly thereafter.
And I grew up in Palestine in East Texas.
Where did you go to college?
Went to Baylor University.
OK. What years did you attend?
I was in Baylor 1948 through 1952.
And where did you go to seminary?
Went to seminary in Fort Worth, Southwestern Baptist Theological Seminary, Fort Worth, Texas.
In what years did you attend seminary?
I was in seminary in 1952 through 1956 the first time.
Okay.
Where were you living in the 1960s?
In the 1960s, I was living in South Houston, Texas, and then Victoria, Texas.
Okay, what was your position in the church?
I was pastor of First Baptist Church, South Houston, Texas, and pastor of First Baptist Church, Victoria, Texas.
Okay, what was the ethnic breakdown of the communities, first in Houston and then in Victoria?
In Houston, South Houston, South Houston is an independent city, though a suburb area of Houston, and the ethnic breakdown
makeup of the community was largely Anglo and Hispanic.
Okay, what about in Victoria?
In Victoria, largely Anglo with a very good-sized Hispanic community and a smaller black community.
Okay, what was ethnic breakdown of the church?
In South Houston, we had a few
Most of the Hispanic people were in a mission that our church sponsored on the east side of the town.
So was that mission 100% Hispanic then?
Some of our Anglo people from our church worked in the mission.
So I would say that it was probably 98% Hispanic.
What about the pastor of that mission?
He was Hispanic.
He was Hispanic, too?
Uh-huh.
OK, how would you characterize
the race relations in the church.
Race relations in the South Houston church with the mission people was good.
And as I said, occasionally we did have some Hispanic people who were in our congregation too.
I cannot recall any problems, but by the large, they were two separate congregations, of course.
What about in Victoria?
What was the ethnic breakdown of the church there?
Our church was largely Anglo.
We did have a number of Hispanic children who attended our church.
And we had one black member in the church in Victoria while I was there.
Was there any mission church in Victoria?
Yes, there was a Hispanic mission.
There was no black mission.
There were two or three very strong black congregations in the city, and we had very good relationships with them.
Were they Southern Baptist churches?
No, the black congregations were not Southern Baptist.
As I recall, the predominant or the largest black congregation was the National Baptist Church.
Okay, and they had black pastors?
Yes.
How would you characterize the Southern Baptist Convention
and their position on race relations within the church.
The convention position, and I think I'm correct in this, was that our churches needed to do more to establish better racial relations and to be more open to other racial groups becoming a part of
churches that were largely Anglo churches in those days.
Okay.
So what was the role of minorities in the church?
Was it mainly just membership in the church?
Or did they assume a more active role?
Well, the minorities were such minorities that they did not have a great effect in the church, as I recall.
The Hispanic community and
South Houston was very small.
The one black member that we had in Victoria was very active in the church choir.
Okay.
How did the other people view that black member in Victoria?
There was no problem whatsoever in the church in Victoria.
If there had been a larger segment of another racial group, it might have been different, but with a black member who happened to be a lady, there was no problem at all.
Do you think it would have been different had that black member been a man?
I don't think so, no.
Okay.
Did any black churches in that time fall under the domain of the Southern Baptist Convention?
There were a few black churches during that time.
I recall, I believe I'm correct, there was one church in Corpus Christi that affiliated with the Southern Baptist Convention.
Of course, since then,
there have been large numbers of black congregations that have affiliated with the Southern Baptist Convention.
Okay, and those black churches then had black pastors too?
Yes.
Were there any minority congregations with white pastors?
I was not aware of any in either of those two communities during those years, no.
What about white congregations with black or Hispanic pastors?
I don't recall any.
How did the church and Southern Baptist Convention view black ministers who led the civil rights movement such as Martin Luther King?
I think probably that would depend on individuals within the churches as well as individual pastors and in the way that they looked at the civil rights movement.
There was still in those days a good amount of prejudice, but I would say by the large,
I'd say probably most of the pastors were sympathetic to the civil rights movement.
There were some things that happened that they probably didn't like, as oftentimes happen when change is occurring like that.
What would you say were some of those things that they didn't like?
Oh, I have an idea that there was still a racial or color prejudice among some of the people.
And some of them felt like that, well, you know, it was the right thing to do, but they were moving too fast.
Some of them may have had that attitude.
Of course, if they had been in the minority group, they wouldn't have felt that way probably.
Right.
How did the Ku Klux Klan affect the church?
I cannot recall either in Houston or in Victoria that the Klan was...
active in those communities during the time that I was pastor there.
Did you ever hear of any experiences where the Klan had affected another church?
Primarily just in news articles, reading about it, or perhaps on television.
Okay.
Kneel-ins, where people would kneel in segregated churches, grew in popularity in the 1960s.
Were there any kneel-ins that you encountered?
No, I do not recall any.
Did you ever hear of any that had happened at all?
No.
After I left Victoria, this was getting on into the 70s, though, it was the end of the 60s, when I moved from Victoria to a church in Texarkana.
There had been two churches that had been set on fire in Texarkana, and as I went to the

church where I served in Texarkana, which was the Beach Street First Baptist Church on the Arkansas side, the church had been actively raising funds to help rebuild the two black churches that had been burned.
Who burned the churches down?
I'm not sure they ever found out who did.
Did you find a difference in race relations between Arkansas and Texas?
Perhaps a little.
There may have been a bit more prejudice at that time.
Of course, when you move from Victoria, which is in South Texas, it's different.
And when you come across East Texas and on into Arkansas, there probably was more prejudice in East Texas and in Arkansas than there was in South Texas, for instance.
What would you say accounted for that?
I think historical location.
and the fact that in East Texas and Arkansas, there were a larger segment of black people than there had been in South Texas.
But the attitude of the people in Texarkana at the time that I went there, I felt like, was a very good attitude, not a bad attitude.
Do you think that it changed dramatically since, say, the early 60s in that area?
the school issue up there and so on.
And I'm sure that filtered down to all the other communities in Arkansas.
But yes, I think there was a better attitude by then.
Okay, the Civil Rights Act of 1964 granted blacks equal access to all public facilities.
Churches, private institutions, however, what effect did the Civil Rights Act of 1964 have on the church?
I doubt that it had very much effect on the church at all.

In fact, I think there were already some churches that were responding and opening their doors to blacks, although there were many, many sad to say that had not done so and that quite frankly still do not do so.
So there was a great deal of segregation at that time?
In the churches?
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, there was.
How did the church in the Southern Baptist Convention justify the segregation?
I don't think they justified it.
I can't recall any denominational leadership justifying it, and I personally never did justify it.
In fact, in the churches where I pastored, I preached and shared with the people and sought to lead them in the direction of realizing that
In a Christian institution, there was no difference.
God certainly saw no difference.
And that we needed to begin to change our attitudes and realize that all people were welcome in God's house.
Right.
How did, was it just then by like a tradition or what was expected that the blacks went to the black church and whites went to the white church?
Or was there some kind of movement forcing the whites into the white church and the blacks
forcing the blacks away from the white church.
No, I think it was traditionally what happened over the years after the end of slavery.
Of course, in those days, black people were members of white churches.
Slaves were members of the churches where their masters were.
And after freedom, why, there came a gradual segregation that I guess whites helped and blacks also probably contributed to.
It was
And by the 60s, it was sort of a traditional thing.
There were black churches and white churches.
A lot of the people had never stopped to think about it, really.
That's just the way it was in the community.
So were there a great deal of integrated churches then at that time also?
Now, which time are you talking about?
In the 60s.
In the 60s.
Did that integration work?
No, there were not a large number of integrated churches, not in the communities where
are even later in Texarkana.
But with the passing of time, I think there was a changing of attitude.
I know that our people in, of course, in Victoria, we did have a black member and could have had others had they wanted to come.
In Texarkana, it was a little bit different.
But we did have blacks visit at the services from time to time, though we never did have any that joined the church in Texarkana.
Do you think that the blacks felt welcome in the church?
I know that you tried to make them feel welcome.
I'm not sure that they did feel welcome.
Some of them probably did.
While there were others that probably felt like they wouldn't be welcome.
And I'm sure during those days, still, there was an element within many of our white churches that didn't feel that they really wanted black people to come.
At the other end, there were also some people that would have been very happy for them to come.
It was part of the change.
And of course, it didn't take place overnight.
Still, it's not taking place, sadly enough.
So you said that there's an element that really didn't want the blacks in the church.
How did those individuals justify the segregation?
I don't think they had any way to justify it except
Through their own prejudice, of course, as you may be aware, there are some people who take certain portions of the Scripture and say, here's a justification for it.
But I personally do not believe that there's any justification of Scripture for it.
And I think most white Christians realize that there's not.
What was their biblical and scriptural justification for that?
They probably went back to the Old Testament, for instance, after
the flood and the stories, the accounts of the sons of Noah, Ham, Shem, and Japheth, and their son who say that one of those was probably black or was the forerunner of the black race.
I don't think there's any justification for that at all in scripture.
So they say that either Ham, Shem, or Japheth was a black?
Or was the forerunner of the black race.
I don't know how in the world they would justify that one of the boys was black and the other one weren't.
Right.

Have you ever encountered a belief that Jesus was, you know, perhaps of darker color or of, you know, you always see him pictured with the long hair and the, you know, blonde and blue eyes, but have you ever encountered a belief that, you know, maybe Jesus was of darker skin?
on blue eyes.

Most of the pictures or concepts that I've had since I was a boy was that he had dark hair and dark eyes and probably an olive complexion, certainly not a real white complexion like you might expect people from northern parts of the world to have, but rather dark complected.
But I never had thought of him, you know, until recent years as being black.
And I'm not sure there's any justification for his being black any more than there was for him being real white, colored white, or with blue eyes and blonde hair.
Right.
In the 1960s, there were many demonstrations, riots, and violent attacks.
Did you ever deal with any riots, demonstrations, or attacks?
No, I was never in a community or a situation where that occurred when I was present.
Were there any other churches in the area that had problems with race relations?
Not that I'm aware of, no.
OK. How were the churches funded at that time?
Was it mainly through donations?
The Southern Baptist Church is where I was pastor.
Yes, free will offerings as they had been for years and still are.
Right.
What effect do you think the lower economic position of minorities had on their position in the church?
I think it may have had some effect.
Southern Baptists years ago were primarily a low economic people.
That has changed through the years and now we have become more middle income and even in some cases higher income.
And I think Southern Baptists have
probably for several decades now, to their own detriment, neglected lower income people, not just black, but whites and others as well.
But I do think that that has had some effect in the racial area also, because oftentimes racial minorities are in the lower economic end of the spectrum.
I know when I was pastor in Victoria,
that I made an effort to try to enlist some Hispanic families in our church, primarily by trying to enlist their children to begin with.

I would oftentimes go and pick up the boys and girls and bring them to church for several Sundays, and then find one of our church families who would take my place and begin to go by and pick up the children and try to cultivate those families.
As it is evident in just about all walks of life, not just in the religious area of life, human beings have a way of sort of dividing themselves according to socioeconomic groups.
And that has happened in the church.
And it's sad because I feel like the church ought to be open not only to all people of all races, but also all people of all economic stratus.
How did the families of those children feel when a white pastor was taking their kids to church?
Did you ever encounter any conflict?
No, no.
In fact, they were very appreciative.
And occasionally, one of those parents would visit the church.
We were never really very successful in reaching entire families.
But some of those children remained in the church and grew up and finished high school and were young adults in the church and were still there.
So how do you feel that that affected the integration of the church?
I think it helped some.
But by and large, there still has not been an across the board integration in most of our churches even today.
And I think part of the fault of that lies on both sides, both minorities as well as the majority.
When you said that you feel that today the church has neglected some of the lower socioeconomic positions,
In what ways do you mean?
Well, I think it's a fairly well established fact that most people join themselves together in social groups.
And oftentimes, the basis of those social groups is economic income.
And I feel that Baptists have moved up the ladder in income.
And as they have, for the most part, moved up the ladder, they have sometimes forgotten where they have come from in earlier years if they were on the lower part of the economic ladder.
And I think Baptists are beginning to realize that now, Southern Baptists are, and are beginning to try to do more to reach out into communities
to lower income people and try to reach them for Christ, better than we were doing, say, a decade or two ago.
What accounted for the rise in socioeconomic status?
Oh, I think an increase in education, for one thing, would have contributed to it, plus the experience of one family desiring their children to
to be better off than they were.
You oftentimes hear about that.
I don't want my kids to go through what I had to go through.
And so there was an elevation in terms of livelihood, income, education.
And these things all tended to elevate, I think, the people.
Do you think that the socioeconomic position of the Southern Baptist has risen
at a different rate than that of other denominations?
No, not really so.
I think the same things happened to Methodists, Presbyterians, and others as well.
Okay.
At the time when there were segregated churches, what were the differences between the services in minority churches as opposed to white churches?
Well, not just what were the differences then, but there are still differences today.
Hispanic people, black people, I'm sure the same thing is true of Asian people because while in Texarkana, our church sponsored two Vietnamese families and helped them to get settled down over here.
Culture, tradition, both have an effect on the type of worship that people have, not only in this country but other countries as well.
And I think it becomes evident when you travel to other countries and realize that even for Baptists in other countries, they are not exactly the same as they are here in the States.
The same thing is true in the black culture here or in the Hispanic culture.
There are things that have been handed down through their families.
There are traditions.
There are folkways.
they enter into ours as well.
And they make differences in the approach in the black churches.
Their services, I would say, for those that I have visited in and I have preached in black churches on occasion, their worship is somewhat freer.
I wish sometimes that our white people could,
and in being vocal about their faith and in praising the Lord.
I know I've served in missions in Africa overseas, too.
And I see something of that in the black people in Africa that certainly has been brought over into the black people here.
And there are a lot of good things in all of those cultures that each one of our different cultures could probably
benefit from if we share it more often.
Okay.
When you did preach in the black churches, how were you receptive there?
Oh, very well.
I loved preaching in black congregations.
They are usually more responsive than our white people are to preaching.
And there is not such a sense of time in having to get through as there is in our white congregations also.
Why do you think that is?
What accounts for those differences?
Well, I don't know.
I think partly it's their background.
Their lifestyle is a bit different.
They're not rushed.
I think our white people so oftentimes talk, goes back partly to the economic thing.
You know, we're so busy.
Sometimes we've been busy making money and building successful businesses and so on like that.
that has not taken hold of the black community or maybe the Hispanic community.
It probably will in succeeding generations.
I expect there will be a repetition of what's happened to our own white people in this country in those areas too as time goes on.
When was the first time that minorities assumed a leadership role within the church?
I'm not sure the question that you're asking.
I don't think that minorities have assumed a leadership position.
You're talking about the denomination or a local church?
Yes, in the church, in the Son of Baptist Church.
Okay, the Son of Baptist Convention.
Let's talk about the convention.
Yes.
Because that would be different.
Well, there are both blacks and Hispanics who have assumed some leadership positions in
Southern Baptist circles in recent years.
For instance, in Texas Baptist circles, there is a black department in our Texas Baptist convention now.
And there is a Hispanic Baptist convention in Texas has been for a number of years.
And so leadership roles have been assumed for, oh, I'd say the last 10 to 20 years more so than in the past.
Now the local church,
I really can't speak to that because I've not been in a church where there were leaders in the local congregation from the minority groups.
When you're talking about the Hispanic Baptist Convention and the Black Circle, is that all part of the Southern Baptist Convention?
Does that fall under their jurisdiction?
No, I was talking primarily about the Texas Baptist Convention, which is totally independent of the Southern Baptist Convention.
Baptist government is a little bit different from other denominations.
It really begins with the most power being exerted in the local congregation and the state and the Southern Baptist Convention actually
all of the local congregations.
Okay.
How would you characterize race relations in other denominations as compared to the Southern Baptists?
I really don't know that much about the
of the other mainline denominations that they have proceeded a bit more rapidly than Southern Baptists have, to my chagrin.
But I don't know actually on a local basis how much that is true.
Which denominations do you think progress the fastest and the slowest?
I think Southern Baptists have been altogether slower than they should have been.
other denominations that perhaps have moved faster.
Maybe the perhaps Christian church, maybe the Methodist and Presbyterians have moved faster than we have, though I'm not sure of that.
Okay.
When the integration did occur, how did the white members of the church respond to this acceptance of minorities in the church?
Was there any instance when the churches became more integrated where white members, you know, quit the church?
I'm sure there have been cases where integrations occur where probably white members pulled out of the church because they were opposed to it.
I've not been pastor where that has happened, but I've heard of instances where it has happened.
When you were in Victoria and the one black member,
Was she already in the church when you arrived there?
No, she joined after I was there.
And there was no conflict in the church?
No problem.
Did the minority members participate in all aspects of the church life?
Well, in that case, you're speaking about just one, of course.
And no, she participated primarily just on Sunday morning and was active in the church choir.
OK.
As it became more integrated, did minorities in general, speaking in general about this church, did they assume a role in all aspects of the church life?
Or were they limited in their scope to, say, just Sunday mornings?
No.
I think now, speaking from the standpoint of the convention and not a local church, that they have increasingly
had some influence, and I think that will grow from now on, that there's going to be an increasing influence among minorities in the Southern Baptist Convention.
Okay.
I was told that some people believed during the 60s and really earlier than the 60s that minorities, in particular blacks, did not have souls.
What was your experience as far as encountering this belief?
I never encountered that.
I doubt that very many people believed that.
At what point during the Civil Rights Movement did the church change from being segregated to being integrated, or do you think there was not just one pivotal incident?
No, I don't think there was a pivotal incident because the civil rights laws that came about really did not affect the church so much as it did
public governmental agencies and so on like that, schools and stores, businesses, and so on like that.
But I think it is happening gradually.
I think it has still not happened in many, many of our churches.
And hopefully, as the years go by, it will happen more often.
You were talking about the dynamics of the government
and the Southern Baptist Convention.
So would you say that the change will have to occur more from a bottom-up standpoint or more from a top-down?
I think it occurred more from a top-down, and I think it should have occurred more from a bottom-up, but it didn't.
Can you explain on that a little more?
I think the churches should have taken the lead in being more open to the minorities from a Christian perspective.
from the perspective of, you know, that they were all God's children.
And the color of skin didn't really make a difference to the Lord.
It shouldn't make a difference in his churches.
And I think that the churches should have, and I still think they should.
It's a very difficult area, though.
It still is today, a very difficult area.
But I think people are realizing more and more their responsibility and are more and more open
Did the church ever change its doctrine and move towards integration?
I cannot recall Southern Baptist churches changing any doctrine, no.
Do you remember any incidents at all that significantly affected the church and its move towards integration?
As a denomination, I think the civil rights laws did affect it.
it made it begin to think more and more about the fact that segregation enforced was really not right.
Of course, you can't make people go where they don't want to go, whether they're white, black, Hispanic, Asiatic, or any others.
But there was really not the freedom and the openness to go.
that there should have been and that there still needs to be.
Were the seminaries, like Southwestern and Fort Worth, was that an integrated seminary?
Yes, yes.
There were not many black students when I was there, but there were some.
There were Hispanics that were there.
And increasingly, of course, there have been students from other races that were there.
In the seminary, of course, we studied race relations in ethics courses and so on.
So were there any segregated seminaries at the time?
I do not know.
There may have been, but I doubt that any of our Southern Baptist seminaries were segregated at the time.
I think they were open.
Okay.
How would you...
characterize in general the race relations in the church today?
I still think it's got a long ways to go.
I still think there are people who have a great deal of prejudice.
I see that being broken down more and more, and I think that's a good sign.
Part of the problem is, and we discussed a little while ago, is that the type of services are different.
And I think oftentimes Hispanic people prefer their own type service.
Black people prefer their own type service.
White people prefer theirs.
But I think there's a richness in all of these backgrounds, traditions, if you would call them that, that all of them could benefit from some.
For the most part, I think people want to go with their
on so-called racial group, but I think all the churches ought to be open to those people who might not want to and who might want to participate or be active in any other racial group.
Okay.
What portion of Southern Baptist churches today would you say are integrated?
Matt, I really don't have any idea.
I don't know.
I would say probably
Less than half of them are still integrated, maybe more than that.
But in the local area, I've served only in the states of Texas and Arkansas.
And of course, Sotheby's Convention encompasses all of the states of the United States.
And how prevalent integration is, I'm sure it's more so in the northeast in our churches and probably in the far west than it still is in the old south.
But to what degree, I don't know.
If half of our churches are integrated, I would be surprised.
Hopefully, more than half of them would be open to integration if people of other races came.
So what effect do you think geographic barriers have on that segregation, as opposed to just the mindsets of the people there?
Oh, I think geography has something to do with mindsets, too.
I think they're interrelated, of course.
And in the South, segregation has been more difficult, although there are many instances up north of racial problems that are just as severe as they are in the South, too.
I think there's a growing awareness in the South, which might be thought of as the stronghold of segregation there.
There's still a lot of people, I'm sure, who are very bitterly prejudiced.
But gradually, I do think it is changing.
Well, that concludes all my questions.
Is there anything else you'd like to add about anything?
No, nothing that I know of, Matthew.
I've enjoyed talking with you, and I hope it helps.
Well, I appreciate your time, and thank you very much.
